segments.en: Middle Discourses 120
Rebirth by Choice
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
“Mendicants!”
“Venerable sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:
“I shall teach you rebirth by choice.

segments.pli: taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhāya samannāgato hoti, sīlena samannāgato hoti, sutena samannāgato hoti, cāgena samannāgato hoti, paññāya samannāgato hoti.
segments.en: “Take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
They think:

segments.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā khattiyamahāsālānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
segments.en: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’

segments.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
segments.en: They settle on that thought, stabilize it and develop it.

segments.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā ca vihārā ca evaṃ bhāvitā evaṃ bahulīkatā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattanti.
segments.en: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattati.
segments.en: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhāya samannāgato hoti, sīlena samannāgato hoti, sutena samannāgato hoti, cāgena samannāgato hoti, paññāya samannāgato hoti.
segments.en: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

segments.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṃ … pe …

well-to-do householders.’

‘The Gods of the Four Great Kings are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

the Gods of Yama …
the Joyful Gods …
the Gods Who Love to Create …

‘The Brahmā of a thousand is long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

segments.en: Now the Brahmā of a thousand meditates determined on pervading a galaxy of a thousand solar systems,

segments.pli: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā tepi pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
segments.en: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.

segments.en: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

segments.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na katthaci upapajjatī”ti.
segments.en: And, mendicants, that mendicant is not reborn anywhere.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
segments.en: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha explains how one can make a wish to be reborn in different realms.
